d36f36df564965b7ca3b198a61aac579.label: You can also indicate what translator level is allowed to translate those translation keys.

7999808000f97f25922416b2f99a238c.label: You can use blocks to indicate the source language of all of the items inside.

776627462d147ed66ee609d091e37826.label: Sources are used for caching and management of translation keys.

eb0ed62064577b9e7e5f91b3ea725c26.label: One of the main uses cases for the blocks are grouping keys into sources.

9650192d5b8094dd7a75d89d7569dead.label: Blocks allow you to apply a set of options to all translation keys within the block.

c8b62b7991cc3a0fb848ad7df11c0e68.label: In grammar, genitive (abbreviated gen; also called the possessive case or second case) is the grammatical case that marks a noun as modifying another noun.

1d7127c4b9a5810d4d25a6c514c7651b.label: No real change to the values here.

9f6afb0bafa7c08cc352d0a7a8da7aac.label: We will also be translating the names of our users, in order to get a better picture of how the names get adjusted.

8e23d6f745f5ff6a206eeedcb7fd61fb.label: Let's use Russian language to see some more advanced language cases in action.

4baf8669bbe712bb276457bd8cd1c1f1.label: Language cases allow you to manipulate the values of the data passed through tokens.

cada8676b21787ed79a08c62580e9c71.label: In languages like Hebrew, the list rules may include cases such as when all members of the list are male, female or have mixed genders. In Russian, the list rules may include cases for single member male, female, unknown or multiple members.

fcb78d57c637c05e3f2f74c5ab7d1c2d.label: You can encode the entire structure in one sentence:

3532752f32479dc371a1f9c4f0ca90f8.label: Dates can also be used for contextual evaluation.

fd9ecdcf20a6086167efd4e3665f3cc2.label: Sometimes tokens need to be implied:

56128d0948862377fb47b4c62b1b5073.label: Similarly to the numeric rules, some language have dependencies on the gender.

72f8d0feb47c03de7d0e5082ca4d32bc.label: Translator can provide a translation for each rule or rule combination based on the token values.

4aa45c3d6ac93da4e1729fbd8d06a2d8.label: Languages may have simple or complex numeric rules. For example, in English, there are only two rules for "one" and "other". Slovak languages, like Russian, have 3 rules.

1a6c92ba7c0b4c821d3d420ca0a620f9.label: Context rules are used to provide translations based on a specific value of one or more tokens in a sentence.

5d312df15e714887261fa9ee43b0240a.label: Notice that all of the nested tokens are still translated in-context and allow for very accurate translations.

72841f8c5463a2e6e177c8952e90898b.label: Decoration tokens can be nested and they may contain data tokens as well.

4eb20fe9e58daf8094d058dbcbf4e6c3.label: You can also use the long notation of the decoration token.

fb6f1393f1a31ceae8516aea6ec71560.label: The default tokens can also use named parameters:

33b97dfbfe5ca191d008d6eeac68b281.label: You can also pre-define all your tokens in the configuration. Then you don't need to pass them at all. In the following example, [bold: bold] is already pre-defined in the framework.

cb3ddbba5d233583d643534390d3874f.label: Or they can be defined as strings, where [bold: {$0}] indicates the translated value being passed in.

12dcc9f80a39c5609d2299ee07d4918e.label: The token values can be passed as lambdas.

bb7ee08fd00a1a6a390d86ecdad38ef7.label: In other libraries, like in iOS or Android, the tokens can be substituted with a native decoration framework.

4324d7b5faf1daf912155712d910b514.label: As a general rule, if any of the words of your translation keys depend on a user, use implied tokens. It won't affect default translations, yet it would give translators an option make the translation accurate.

90327f122d412b8b2b521841e344e7c0.label: Even though the base language does not have a gender specific dependency in some cases, it is always good to wrap it with an implied token.

9cc2a27e61cfc431739b702734f9027b.label: Similar to the previous examples, you don't have to provide the named parameter values.

21ac0b514948152320f0878f14fe3f57.label: Implied tokens use a single pipe since the value does not need to be displayed.

45986b9080672ea4107684fc54e14e6e.label: The context rules are specific for each language. But you don't have to worry about it, translators will provide the rules and the values.

842ab404a5bc63f6fba80e4176721f98.label: Single pipe "|" means to not display the actual token value, but display the value that follows based on the context rules.

e17899bea7eacd24c56e1c83f2064916.label: The same exact concept applies to other token types and context rules.

e951138c4e4d8efbc7cb80b1e121893d.label: Since the library comes with default pluralizers, you don't even need to provide the plural form. It will be automagically generated for you.

05fce9446710df4d80e9f1368abb989a.label: Since the sequence of parameters is mapped to the sequence of rules, you can omit naming the parameters.

34ba1632312e94c4b2bd9653c1a6dc2b.label: Double pipe "||" means that the value would be displayed, followed by the word that depends on the value. In this case, if the count value meets the criteria for the rule "one", then it will display the word set to the rule. For all other cases it would display the "other" value.

d223c531a7d042ef43afc5aedcfbda57.label: Piped tokens work in conjunction with context rules and allow you to provide substitution values based on the object values.

cce4f189322467439285d1c80963ced6.label: Method tokens allow you to invoke methods on the object you are passing to get the substitution value.

a471d534bc41be4fdb3349d0442bc562.label: Or you can pass an attribute name of an attribute in the hash.

84ce5bbe1cc2cfaff25eb07127b9a468.label: You can use hashes for the token values as well.

f50d19b21bea7d45a174d5fb29292c15.label: You can also get the substitution value by invoking a method of the object by using a symbol in the second parameter.

50ab3bb6cf7bf881c7c155699ebd3c6d.label: If your translation key needs to use context rules, you can pass the object and the substitution value as an array.

52c2ff9aebf21e6bd7242fe3a6dd57d0.label: You must keep the two parts together to make sure the translations are accurate. You will later see how you can use decoration tokens to fix the above problem.

92baaf34390db236e1f8f6d4063bfdbd.label: The problem with the above example, is that the "registration page" link text would be translated differently based on the context where it appears.

790b2870ff0541d3b91faedf99498b91.label: But make sure that you don't take translations out of context.

f82858dc34871d20f5b89dc74d5ad5e6.label: In many cases your tokens would be string objects that get substituted directly into the translated sentence.

3c0f2ed2ecc1533cca6be53688029fe3.label: It is important to provide the best possible description for each phrase from the start. Keep in mind that changing a description in the future, after it has already been translated, will register a new phrase in the database and invalidate all of its translations. On the other hand, labels that are complete sentences may not need a description as they are fully self-contained.

f02f4a52d9f254153584d4de8d47a5f7.label: For example, the following two phrases will be registered as two independent entries in a database even though the have the same label, but a different description. The user will have to translate each one of them separately as they will have different translated labels in other languages.

d5739f03c63fb052d0328d5edb5a38dd.label: The description serves two purposes: it creates a unique key for each label and it also gives a hint to the translators for the context in which the label is used.

97621ca09b2926a91196cc5c53c44f05.label: As a general rule, you should always provide description to words, phrases and sentences that are only meaningful within a specific context.

082f92bc8f07d4defb96e892c18dcb1b.label: The description of a phrase is not mandatory, but it should be used in cases when the label alone is not sufficient enough to determine the meaning of the sentence being translated.

27cd7ce97ee419f4529b5052efe5ab0b.label: Let's start with a simple phrase:

8da844dd8892ca1b49ae563b642c608d.label: [bold: options] provides a mechanism for passing additional directives to the translation engine.

4edceb55f7b7a5cecda2c735b0aee2ba.label: [bold: tokens] is an optional parameter that contains a hash (or a dictionary) of token values to be substituted in the label.

3d075811c35e2745396b4b14afeb63b2.label: [bold: description] is an optional parameter, but should always be used if the label by itself is not sufficient enough to provide the meaning of the phrase.

f7af4cee788e9633411f1625cdd080ec.label: [bold: label] is the only required parameter.

25d435f614712fa8a3a1aea649cf68b2.label: The function can be called using any of the following ways:

e233d9fc1022e28a1955f4f3940ac2df.label: Translation Markup Language (TML) is used to identify the non-translatable or dynamic data within the labels. It provides a way to mark data and decoration tokens within the strings that need to be translated. There are different types of applications that can use TML - web, mobile and desktop. Some use HTML, others use Wiki-Like syntax for decorating the labels. TML aims at abstracting out the decoration mechanisms of the string used by the applications and instead provides its own simple, but powerful syntax. This allows for translation sharing across multiple applications.

adf8fc5b5197e12f328caa84d5940c6f.label: Alternatively, you can use hashes to represent objects.
